posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
You listed too many feats, David.  The CBC should have flagged duplicates as red.  Illegal feats listed in this build are: BG bonus feat at 27, CoT bonus feat at 30 or 32, fighter bonus at 35, 37 and 39. That's 6 less feats than what is listed here.  Are you sure you are only allocating feats using the drop-down lists on the white cells?  CBC should be warning you about all the illegal feats or just prohibiting the selection.  You didn't accidentally Unprotect the Workbook, did you?

Unless... there are a bunch of bonus feats your server gives to this sort of sequence.  But you would be allocating all those duplicates even in that situation and still be prevented by CBC.

Make sure that you always start out your CBC with a fresh (blank) spreadsheet and, when you save, always save using a unique name (never use the default name CBC2002.xls or whatever version you are using).  I use a naming format like Ftr14_CoT10_BG16_hum.xls.  You may need to add a numeral after the race if you want to keep more than one version of exactly the same class/race combo.  If you lost your fresh CBC version by overwriting it with a build, delete your current CBC2002.xls (or whatever it was) and decompress a fresh one from the zipped file you downloaded.  If you already deleted the zip, DL a new one from the Vault.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Click inside each cell that is not white background with text in the feats columns (ref. AV, BA, BF), then hit the Delete key.  Don't try to delete anymore than one cell content at a time or the workbook thinks you are trying to reformat the entire sheet.  The same goes for any cell that is white background if the text inside is red.  That's an illegal entry which must be deleted, but just one cell at a time.

The spreadsheet will always try to calculate an output even with illegal entries.  That's just the way Kamiryn set it up to work. She uses a cell background scheme and text colors as visual aids to indicate whether you are following the build rules or not.

If you feel your changes have caused too much confusion, then start afresh.  It's usually easier and faster overall that way than try to straighten out all the mistakes. 

One tip I'll pass on... focus only on your class sequence, ability increments and feats first. 

If a class abbreviation shows up red in column B, just ignore it for the time being.  If it is red, check the Class prerequisites (columns BJ-BL at rows 46-50).  Those will describe the BAB, feats and skills needed to satisfy the prestige class.  Set up the feats first and watch the BAB column (N) for each row (level).  When it reaches at least the BAB prereq, your prestige class can be taken on the next level or later.  When the BAB and feats have been satisfied but there is still a skill prereq, scroll over to the skills section (columns EL thru FM) and type in the skill level needed at least one row (level) before where the prestige class is wanted (a white cell of that feat column).  You may need to cross-class if none of the classes own it as a class skill so that would mean typing a number into one of the yellow cells. Only the grey cells are prohibited.  When all prereqs have been satisfied, the red class abreviation will turn black.  That means it is legal at that point in the build.

After repeating this procedure for any other prestige class, finish up allocating all your feats for 1-40.  If you need to swap around the class order to make the feats more optimized do it now.  Delete any telltale (illegal) feats that show up by virtue of your juggling.  These are always bonus feats because the general feats always show every 3 rows nomatter how much you swap around the class sequence. 

Once you are satisfied about the sequence and feat selection, return to the skill section and start laying out your skill schedule.  If you wait until the last step to allocate skills, you won't need to redo them when you are still organizing your ideal class sequence and feats.  It's just less work.  If you are dumping skills, make sure your tumble classes appear on a level with a "2" or "7" in it, like 2, 7, 12, 17, 22 etc.  For UMD, add 1 level to the tumble dump level for each 2 CHA below 10 to get the right dump level.  For example, a normal dwarf (-2 CHA) would do a rogue dump at level 2+2 = "4", 7+2 = "9"... etc since the CHA is 4 points below 10.  This will determine the ideal level to apply your tumble/UMD dumps.

I hope this doesn't all confuse you.  Use it for reference when the occasion arises.

And stick with it.  Eventually, it will become second nature.
